Metadata: Isolation and activation of cathepsin L-inhibitor complex from Pacific whiting ("Merluccius productus")

Pacific whiting muscle tissue, infected with myxosporidia ("Kudoa paniformis"), contains high levels of proteolytic activity. Purification of the enzyme showed that the proteolytic activity is mainly due to cathepsin L as characterized by its chemical inhibition, activity against specific substrates, temperature, and pH profiles. Fractions eluted from a hydrophobic chromatography resin have two activity peaks (P-I and P-II) with an equal amount of total activities when analyzed with azocasein as a substrate. These data lead to several possibilities as to the composition of the peaks, including enzyme-â€‹inhibitor complex and free forms, isozymes, or heavy and light chains. The objective of this study was to characterize the identity of P-I and P-II by analyzing its activity with Z-Phe-Arg-NMec.
